raw_output:
user 
System:
You are extracting factual relations from a medical imaging lecture. Use only information grounded in the input SLIDE_TEXT.

User:
SLIDE_TEXT:
Now let’s add a third dimension.
Use plot 3 of x, y, z to make a 3D line plot.
For surfaces, use the mesh command — it draws a grid over the surface defined by z values.
If you want a contour plot — use contour z matrix. That shows level curves of a surface.
You can also control the axis limits with axis, add a title with title, and label the axes using x label and y label.
To explain the meaning of different curves, use legend.

STRICT INSTRUCTIONS:
- Return JSON only. No prose, no markdown, no code fences.
- Output a triple only if both subject and object appear verbatim in SLIDE_TEXT (case-insensitive).
- Predicates must be one of: uses | via | represents | depends_on | measures | produces | reconstructs_with.
- Add modalities ["text"] by default; add "image" only if the relation is clearly visible without the text.
- confidence in [0,1]. Do not invent entities or relations.

OUTPUT:
{
  "triples": [
    {"s":"<verbatim subject>", "p":"uses|via|represents|depends_on|measures|produces|reconstructs_with",
     "o":"<verbatim object>", "modalities":["text","image"], "confidence":0.0, "evidence":"<short quote from SLIDE_TEXT>"}
  ]
}
assistant
{
  "triples": [
    {"s":"3D line plot", "p":"uses", "o":"plot 3 of x, y, z", "modalities":["text"], "confidence":0.0, "evidence":"For surfaces, use the mesh command — it draws a grid over the surface defined by z values."}
  ]
}

triples.evidence: For surfaces, use the mesh command - it draws a grid over the surface defined by z values.
